awd_titl_txt: Conical Radon transforms and their applications in tomography
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses a number of mathematical problems of image reconstruction in several emerging fields of imaging. Specific topics include single scattering optical tomography and gamma-ray emission tomography, which are used in medicine for diagnostics and treatment monitoring of various diseases. The project also considers Compton camera imaging, which is used for detection of radiation sources in homeland security and in radio astronomy. The outcomes of this project have potential impact for modern healthcare technologies, national security, exploration of space, and several industrial applications. A special emphasis in this project is made on training students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM fields, including women and minorities.

The project is devoted to the study of broken ray (BRT) and conical (CRT) Radon transforms, and their applications to several modern imaging modalities. BRT is a transform that maps a function defined on a plane to its integrals along a certain family of broken rays. CRT maps a function defined in the 3D space to its integrals over a family of conical surfaces. These quantities often correspond to measurements of an imaging device, and the process of image reconstruction depends on the possibility of stable inversion of these transforms. The central problems addressed by the investigators include: the description of injectivity sets of BRT/CRT and formulas for their inversion, the study of the microlocal properties of these transforms, the description of their range, and the investigation of incomplete data problems. The methodology to attack such problems utilizes various combinations of techniques from Fourier analysis, partial differential equations, integral equations and microlocal analysis.

por.por_cntn:
In this project the investigators studied several novel integral transforms appearing in imaging applications utilizing single-scattered particles (typically photons). These generalized Radon-type transforms map an image function, a vector field or a higher order tensor field to its integrals along various trajectories or surfaces with a single vertex. Examples of such transforms include the V-line or broken-ray transform (BRT) integrating along broken lines, conical Radon transforms (CRT) integrating along circular or polygonal cones, and the star transform integrating along a union of rays emanating from a common vertex. These integration trajectories typically correspond to the paths of photons flying through the object under investigation, with their vertices corresponding to scattering locations inside the body. The latter feature plays a distinguishing role for these studies, since most of the recent research on Radon-type transforms with a vertex in the path of integration has been dedicated to the setups, where the vertex is either outside or on the boundary of the imaging object.

The central problems addressed in the studies were injectivity of the aforementioned transforms, derivation of exact inversion formulas and/or approximate inversion algorithms for these transforms in various practically important geometries of data acquisition, analysis of stability of inversion procedures, investigation of microlocal properties of the transforms, and description of their range.

In the case of a scalar image function, the investigators obtained several new inversion formulas for the BRT, CRT and star transform with weights in various geometric setups. The formulas were obtained by developing a novel approach to the study of these transforms (cone differentiation), which gave a clear geometric insight and provided much simpler proofs to several previously known results. In addition to that, they provided a new range description for BRT in the case of fixed opening angle in 2D. They also developed accurate and robust numerical algorithms using the obtained inversion formulas and tested them on synthetically generated data with and without noise.

In addition to the scalar case, the investigators proposed several new generalized V-line transforms of vector fields and studied their inversion in three different ways. In particular, they introduced the longitudinal (LVT) and transverse (TVT) V-line transforms, their corresponding first moment transforms, and the weighted star transform of vector fields in the plane. The research team provided an explicit characterization of the kernels of LVT and TVT and showed that they are complements of each other. The investigators proved invertibility of each transform modulo their kernels and combined them to reconstruct explicitly the full vector field. In the second method, they combined the longitudinal and transverse V-line transforms with their corresponding first moment transforms and recovered the full vector field from either pair. Finally, they derived an exact closed form formula for reconstruction of the full vector field in the plane from its star transform with weights. Several other interesting results have been obtained on recovering the full symmetric m-tensor field on a compact Riemann surface from ray transforms, moment ray transforms and mixed ray transforms, as well as on microlocal analysis of a restricted ray transform on symmetric m-tensor fields in the Euclidean space.

Based on the original results of this project, the investigators published 12 refereed papers in high quality international journals and 1 book chapter. One more paper is currently under review, and three others are in preparation. The PI and Co-PI made 25 presentations at various conferences and seminars around the world disseminating the outcomes of their work.

Both investigators have a strong track record of mentoring students. As a result of the scientific work supervised by the PI and Co-PI, their students have won research awards, published joint papers with them, presented their work at various conferences, and got admitted to highly ranked graduate programs or found excellent job positions related to their research. During 4 years of the project, the PI involved in research related to this project and supervised: 3 PhD students (including 1 Hispanic and 1 female), 2 MS students (1 female) and 11 undergraduate students (1 Hispanic + 5 female), all in USA. In the same period, the Co-PI co-supervised 1 PhD student in USA, and 5 PhD students in India, one of which has moved to USA and is currently a postdoctoral fellow working with the PI.

The project addressed multiple mathematical problems that are of significance in several emerging fields of imaging. The techniques related to this research include single-scattering optical tomography, single-scattering in x-ray tomography, and gamma-ray emission tomography used in medicine for diagnostics and treatment monitoring of various diseases, as well as Compton camera imaging used for detection of radiation sources in homeland security and in radio astronomy. As a result, the outcomes of this project can have a considerable impact on modern healthcare technologies, national security, exploration of space, and several industrial applications.
